newsitem.title: USA: NYMEX electricity near months up amid outages.
newsitem.headline: NYMEX electricity near months up amid outages.

text.p: NYMEX electricity futures contracts for April and May moved higher amid planned and unplanned power plant outages in the West, while forward contracts were little changed.
"There are quite a few outages which are pushing up PV (Palo Verde), which in turn is pushing up COB (California-Oregon border)," said one dealer.
"But it is still pretty boring out there," she added.
As of 1250 EST, April COB was last 20 cents at $9.75 per megawatt hour (MWh), while May was up 15 cents at $9.90.
PV for April was up 45 cents at $13.60, while May was up 35 cents at $13.60.

Although a series of storms could plague the Northwest into the weekend, the region was expected to see near normal temperatures through Wednesday before cooling to two to four degrees F below normal.
In the Southwest, readings were expected to run four to eight degrees above normal for the next couple of days.
The outage of the 1,070 megawatt (MW) San Onofre nuclear unit 2 in southern California was extended due to discovery of a pressurizer leak on Monday.
The Nuclear Regulatory Commission said the unit was now expected to restart March 13, but a spokesman for Southern California Edison Co said a timeframe for further repairs remained uncertain.
The San Onofre unit has been shut since November 30 for refueling and assorted repair work and the plant's 1,080 MW unit 1 is due to start a refueling outage April 5.

Other plant outages in the Southwest include the 1,221 MW Palo Verde 3 nuclear unit, the 750 MW Navajo coal-fired unit, a 750 MW unit at the Mohave coal-fired plant and a 300 MW coal-fired unit at the Reid Gardner plant in Nevada.
In addition, the 1,158 MW WNP-2 nuclear unit in Washington was expected to ramp down Wednesday night for an extended refueling outage due to last until early July.
